Indications and doses

Susceptible infections (including urinary-tract infections, otitis media, sinusitis, uncomplicated community-acquired pneumonia, salmonellosis),

By intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    0.5–1 g every 6 hours.
  • For adults
    500 mg every 4–6 hours.
  • For adults
    500 mg every 4–6 hours.
  • For children 1–11 months
    125 mg 4 times a day; increased if necessary up to 30 mg/kg 4 times a day.
  • For children 1–4 years
    250 mg 4 times a day; increased if necessary up to 30 mg/kg 4 times a day.
  • For children 5–11 years
    500 mg 4 times a day; increased if necessary up to 30 mg/kg 4 times a day (max. per dose 1 g).
  • For children 12–17 years
    500 mg 4 times a day; increased if necessary to 1 g 4 times a day, use increased dose in severe infection.

Endocarditis (in combination with another antibiotic if necessary), Listerial meningitis (in combination with another antibiotic),

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    2 g every 4 hours.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Not known to be harmful.

Advice regarding renal impairment

In adults

Reduce dose if eGFR less than 10 mL/minute/1.73 m2; rashes more common.

In children

If estimated glomerular filtration rate less than 10 mL/minute/1.73 m2 reduce dose or frequency; rashes more common.

With intravenous use

Accumulation of electrolytes contained in parenteral preparations can occur in patients with renal failure.

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Nausea, vomiting,

Rash

If rash occurs, discontinue treatment.

Directions for administration

With oral use

Administer at least 30 minutes before food.

With intravenous use in children

Displacement value may be significant when reconstituting injection, consult local guidelines. Dilute intravenous injection to a concentration of 50–100 mg/mL. May be further diluted with glucose 5% or 10% or sodium chloride 0.9% or 0.45% for infusion. Give over 30 minutes when using doses of greater than 50 mg/kg to avoid CNS toxicity including convulsions.

With intravenous use in adults

For intravenous infusion (Penbritin ), give intermittently in Glucose 5% or Sodium chloride 0.9%. Reconstituted solutions diluted and given without delay; suggested volume 100 mL given over 30–60 minutes

via drip tubing in Glucose 5% or Sodium chloride 0.9%. Continuous infusion not usually recommended.

Advice for patients and carers

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Ampicillin for bacterial infection

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/ampicillin-bacterial-infection

Cautions regarding administration

  • Acute lymphocytic leukaemia (increased risk of erythematous rashes)
  • chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (increased risk of erythematous rashes)
  • cytomegalovirus infection (increased risk of erythematous rashes)
  • glandular fever (erythematous rashes common)
  • With intravenous use: accumulation of electrolytes contained in parenteral preparations can occur with high doses

Unlicensed use

In adults

Ampicillin doses in BNF may differ from those in product literature.
